text: Patient: Potassium was a little off. Doctor: Okay. We’ll, we’ll check you out for that. You know? You’re here because when Dr. S___, he did the lung biopsy or at least he told those guys to do a lung biopsy, it shows prostate cancer in your lungs. So not lung cancer. So in some sense a little bit of a relief but you still have your cancer of the – Patient: Of the prostate. Doctor: - prostate in your lungs. Now, you had that in twenty sixteen. It’s just that there’s more of it and slightly bigger. So that’s why I got you. When I went to, I sent you to Dr. S___, it was like well what are we going to do? Well, I need to take a sample. So he thought about going down this way. If you remember to try to get a sample from that, but he thought getting it through the outside would be just fine. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Which way did it get it? From the left side or right side? Doctor: The biopsy? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Ooh, I want to say left. Uh, I think it was the left, and then they did the special stains underneath the microscope, and, you know, looked for actual prostate stains, and it was positive on both of them. So now the question is, you started your hormone shot back up, and you’ve kind of been on it the whole time. It’s just you were delayed a little bit on one day, one of them, and now it’s you need another medicine. But I want to make sure that you are well healed from your pneumonia before we go ahead and do that. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Probably, you know, another several weeks or so until you feel like you’re back on your feet, uh, and over the flu, the pneumonia, and all that, but we think you’re going to need a set of pills to kind of help keep the prostate in check.

text: Family Member: Is there even someone up that way even? I mean, I don't know. Doctor: I think so. Family Member: I think Dr. F_____. Doctor: They kind of go out like, yeah, there's somebody that's out there like once a week or once a month, they rotate. Family Member: So they come out and do infusions? Doctor: No, I think the infusion people are there all the time. I think the doctors come out every so often. Family Member: Ohh. Okay. Doctor: Don’t quote me. Patient: So I only have to come down once every three weeks? Yeah. Family Member: So what's the difference between the trial infusion timetable and the infusion of just getting the infusions. Doctor: None. It's still once every three weeks. Family Member: Yeah, there's no difference? Doctor: There's no difference. So it's just if you get on the study arm and you get the pill chemo version, then you might have a slightly different schedule. And I should know all that except I rely heavily on my research nurse to make sure that's right. Because they change the schedule sometimes so often, and I'm just gonna so ask S____ to help me.

text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Chemo is the only thing that we know right now – the one that your doctor said may not do a whole lot – he doesn’t have much faith in it is what I think what you told me. Is again, we do know that if you get the drug, tolerate the drug, respond to the drug, people live longer, but again, that’s got an if, if, if. Um. So, that would be what usual is, and then this is research, experimental. Would require you coming down here every other week for a couple of weeks. Patient: Ah huh. Doctor: Uh, and then, uh, every two weeks, three weeks, once you get past the first part, you’re here a lot – so that’s for us to watch you, keep close eye on you as well as to see what the side effects are. Uh. But for you, it’s a downside of coming a distance, coming here a lot, feeling tired, feeling fatigued, and with the uncertainty is this going to do anything? Patient: Right. (Pause) Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But again, if you’re driving, folks driving, getting you here, and again you can go out of this world sayin’, “I’ve tried everything ‘till the end.” Okay? But I still think you need to be careful and pay attention to this. Okay? Because if something goes really bad with this – let’s say you get a bad pneumonia, and we want to put you on a breathing machine even though the steroids may be able to bring you back, we don’t know that. But if it gets to a point, you know, I’m not sure you really should be on a breathing machine. Patient: What kind of breathing machine? Doctor: Uh. A ventilator. On TV. Those are television. Your body’s gotten so sick that if I get you to wake up, you still have the bad cancer. Patient: Oh. Doctor: Okay? So, I also, I mean, I’m not so sure we should be pounding on your chest. Uh, you should be thinking about how far will we go even if it looks bad. (Pause) Patient: No. See, my dad died from prostate cancer in nineteen eighty six. He hadn’t -- didn’t have much treatment at all. Uh. Family Member: He waited, he waited to have severe symptoms. Then he went and then (they’s found)

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
